summary: A step-by-step instructional video guide on upgrading from Windows 8 to Windows 10.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer desktop screen with a captivating background image of a winding road at dusk, illuminated by the streaks of car lights. The road snakes through lush green hills, with a serene body of water visible in the distance, reflecting the soft hues of the sunset sky. The desktop is organized with various icons on the left side, including folders and applications such as Google Chrome, OpenOffice, and Steam. The taskbar at the bottom displays the time as 16:41 and the date as 10/07/2017. The overall atmosphere is tranquil and picturesque, with the natural beauty of the landscape complemented by the dynamic light trails of the moving vehicles.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker welcoming listeners to a tutorial. He announces that he will demonstrate how to upgrade from Windows 8 to Windows 10, describing the process as "very simple" and "very straightforward." He promises the upgrade process will handle data and hard drive partitioning automatically. The speaker then declares that he will prove he doesn't already have Windows 10 before the clip cuts to the sound of a whoosh.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a computer desktop featuring a scenic wallpaper of a winding road at dusk, with light trails from moving vehicles. The desktop is populated with various icons, including folders and applications such as Google Chrome, OpenOffice, and Steam. The taskbar at the bottom shows the time as 10:14 AM. The user navigates to the Start menu, revealing a selection of applications and tiles, including Google Chrome and Weather. The user then accesses the Apps menu, displaying options like PC settings, Control Panel, and DTS Audio Control Panel. The Control Panel window opens, showing categories such as System and Security, Network and Internet, and Hardware and Sound. The user selects the System option, leading to the System window, which provides details about the computer's specifications, including the processor, system type, and RAM. The video concludes with the System window open, displaying the Windows 8 logo and basic information about the computer, including the manufacturer (HP) and the Windows version. The desktop background remains consistent throughout the video, maintaining the scenic view of the winding road at dusk.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker discussing Windows 8.1 and the Start Menu, then transitions to describing how to access the Control Panel via apps, searching for "Control Panel." He then explains navigating to System and Security, and then System, to view system information. He notes the processor type and installed memory. The speaker mentions it's a "64-bit operating system".

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer desktop running Windows 8, with the System window open, displaying basic information about the computer. The desktop background features a scenic image of a winding road through a forested area during twilight, with the sky transitioning from blue to orange hues. The taskbar at the bottom shows the time as 10:16 AM and the date as 10/10/2013. Several icons are visible on the desktop, including Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, and Steam. The System window lists details such as the processor, system type, RAM, and touch input availability. The cursor moves across the screen, hovering over different sections of the System window, but no actions are taken. The overall atmosphere is calm and static, with no significant changes or movements observed throughout the video.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip consists of one male speaker explaining the implications of upgrading to Windows 10 in terms of bit architecture, saying, "When you upgrade to Windows 10... you're going to have 64-bit Windows 10 if you had 64-bit Windows 8 to begin with." He goes on to say that if you started with 32-bit Windows 8, you will have 32-bit Windows 10. He is speaking in an explanatory, instructional tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a computer desktop screen displaying a scenic wallpaper of a winding road at dusk, with various icons such as Google Chrome, Steam, and Recycle Bin visible. The taskbar shows the time as 16:43. A semi-transparent overlay appears, listing various software options like 'Microsoft Office 2016', 'Windows 8', and 'hp'. The overlay then changes to a Microsoft webpage titled 'Download Windows 10', featuring a blue banner and a laptop image with Windows 10 installed. The webpage includes a 'Download tool now' button and instructions for creating Windows 10 installation media. The scene transitions back to the desktop, now with a 'Windows' logo overlay. The video then shows the 'Windows 10 Setup' window, with the message 'Getting a few things ready' and a loading icon, indicating the start of the installation process. The desktop background remains consistent throughout, with the time changing to 16:46. The video concludes with the 'Windows 10 Setup' window still open, showing the same message and loading icon, suggesting the installation is in progress.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker providing instructions on how to access a software download. He suggests using the provided website. The speaker then suggests that a link will be included in the description. Next, a "download now" button will be pressed and this is followed by the completion of the step. This step then leads to the "execution" of the program and the browser can be closed. After closing the browser, the speaker mentions that it will take some time for the program to start. He also describes the "Windows 10 font" and "Windows 10 colors". He explains that the system files, programs, and files won't be erased, rather, the operating system will undergo an "easy upgrade".

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer desktop with a scenic background of a winding road through a mountainous area during twilight, with a purple sky and city lights visible in the distance. The desktop is populated with various icons, including Google Chrome, OpenOffice, and Steam, among others. The main focus is on the Windows 10 Setup window, which initially displays the message "Getting a few things ready" with options to "Back" or "Next." The setup window then transitions to a screen titled "Applicable notices and license terms," presenting the Microsoft Software License Terms and Microsoft Media Creation Tool License Terms, with sections for "United States," "Canada," and "Australia." The user is prompted to either "Decline" or "Accept" the terms. The video concludes with the setup window returning to the "Getting a few things ready" message, indicating the installation process is ongoing. The time on the desktop clock remains at 10:18 PM throughout the video.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a single male speaker who says, "will eventually go to the next window" then, "and that window looks like this."  He proceeds, explaining "these are the basic terms". The same male speaker continues, instructing the listener that they can "not need to read through those, just go ahead and click accept".

events_list.video_caption: The video shows a computer desktop with a Windows 10 setup window open, displaying the message "Getting a few things ready" on a purple background. The desktop wallpaper features a scenic view of a winding road through a lush, mountainous landscape during twilight, with the sky transitioning from blue to pink hues. The taskbar at the bottom shows the time as 10:18 PM and the date as 10/04/2017. Several icons are visible on the desktop, including folders named "My Pictures," "My Documents," "My Music," and "My Videos," as well as shortcuts to applications like Google Chrome, OpenOffice 4.1.5, and Steam. The cursor is positioned near the "Start" button at the bottom of the setup window. The scene remains static throughout the video, with no changes in the desktop environment or the setup window.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with one male speaker discussing concerns about product keys, particularly with Windows 8 and 8.1, and how Windows 10 simplifies the activation process by using the existing key. The speaker clarifies that you no longer need to find or remember your product key, because it communicates with Microsoft to validate itself. He confirms this has happened to him before, emphasizing that he never needed to know his product key. The clip ends with an indistinct sound.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer desktop with a Windows 10 setup window open. The desktop background features a scenic image of a winding road through a lush, mountainous landscape during twilight, with the sky transitioning from purple to orange hues. The taskbar at the bottom displays various application icons, including Google Chrome, Steam, and a clock showing the time as 10:56 PM. The setup window presents two options: "Upgrade this PC now" and "Create installation media (USB flash drive, DVD, or ISO file) for another PC." The cursor hovers over the "Upgrade this PC now" option, indicating a potential selection. The window then transitions to a message stating "Getting a few things ready," suggesting the initiation of the upgrade process. The overall atmosphere is calm and focused, with the setup process being the central activity.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with one male speaker providing computer instructions, saying things like "you come to this window here" and "what you want to do." He explains the upgrade process from Windows 8 to Windows 10, differentiating between upgrading the current PC versus changing architectures or installing on another computer. He concludes by selecting "upgrade this PC now" and mentions the screen will pause for a bit. Finally, a computer mouse click is heard.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a computer desktop screen displaying a Windows 10 setup window, indicating that 8GB of free disk space is needed on the C: drive. The desktop background features a scenic image of a winding road through a lush, green landscape during twilight, with the sky transitioning from purple to orange hues. Various desktop icons are visible, including folders named "My Pictures," "My Documents," and "My Music," as well as shortcuts to applications like Google Chrome, OpenOffice, and Steam. The taskbar at the bottom shows the time as 10:57 PM and the date as 10/27/2014. The cursor is positioned over the "Next" button in the setup window. The scene then transitions to the Control Panel window, specifically the "System and Security" category, with the cursor hovering over the "Uninstall or change a program" link. The desktop background remains unchanged, and the time on the taskbar has advanced to 11:13 PM. The Control Panel window lists various system and security options, including "Windows Firewall," "System," "Windows Update," "Power Options," "File History," "Storage Spaces," "Work Folders," "Add Features to Windows 8.1," "Administrative Tools," and "Flash Player (32-bit)." The cursor is now positioned over the "Uninstall or change a program" link, indicating the user's intention to proceed with the setup process.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker describing what to do if your computer doesn't have enough space for the installation process, saying to "remove some files". He suggests that you can download them or "install them again later". He then recommends using the "free up disk space" feature to clean up unnecessary files. Next, there is a brief, unidentifiable sound effect. The speaker then says "All right".

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer desktop with a Windows 10 setup window open, indicating the process of downloading Windows 10. The desktop background features a scenic image of a winding road through a lush, mountainous landscape during twilight, with the sky transitioning from purple to orange hues. The taskbar at the bottom displays various application icons, including Google Chrome, Steam, and a clock showing the time as 12:48 AM. The setup window, titled "Downloading Windows 10," includes a progress bar that starts at 0% and gradually increases to 99%, with the text "Feel free to keep using your PC" displayed below the progress bar. The window also has two buttons labeled "Back" and "Next." The desktop icons on the left side include folders named "My Pictures," "My Documents," and "My Music," as well as shortcuts to applications like Google Chrome, OpenOffice 4.1.5, and Steam. The Recycle Bin icon is visible in the bottom right corner. The video captures the steady progression of the Windows 10 download process, with the progress bar moving from 0% to 99% over time.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features a single male speaker explaining that if there is at least 8 gigabytes of free space on the PC, the download process will begin, which will take some time. He then suggests skipping through this part. We then hear the speaker say that the download took him about 30 minutes and that the user can still use the PC while it downloads, implying that someone does not need to remain idle. There is a "click" sound somewhere in between the sentences that may be a mouse click or a similar sound.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer desktop with a scenic background of a winding road through a lush, mountainous landscape during twilight, with light trails from moving vehicles. The desktop is adorned with various icons, including Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, and Steam. A Windows 10 setup window is prominently displayed, initially showing the message "Verifying your download" with a progress bar at 0%. The window then transitions to "Creating Windows 10 media" with a progress bar advancing from 73% to 83%. Subsequently, the setup window disappears, revealing the full desktop background. A new window appears with the message "Preparing 94%" and then changes to "Checking your PC." Finally, the setup window displays "We're getting a few things ready," indicating the ongoing installation process. The time on the taskbar remains at 1:43 AM throughout the video, and the desktop environment remains consistent with no visible human presence or interaction.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features one speaker, who is male. First, he states that he will now perform a "verifying procedure" that will take a "decent amount of time." He then says, "At some point during this process it's gonna switch over to saying it's creating Windows 10 media, not to be alarmed. That's the same thing." He later states that the process is finished and that the computer will clean up, and then shut off. Next he comments that he will switch over to his phone. This transitions into the sound of clicking, followed by a bootup sound of a computer. The speaker then returns, saying that the computer will "quickly check for updates" and "check for PC, it's getting a few things ready before it starts to boot from Windows 10 media".

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer desktop with a scenic background of a winding road through a mountainous area during twilight. The desktop is adorned with various icons, including Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, and Steam. The focus is on the Windows 10 Setup process, which begins with a dialog box titled "Applicable notices and license terms," displaying Microsoft's software licensing terms and a "Decline" and "Accept" button. The user accepts the terms, and the setup proceeds to "Getting updates," indicating the process of checking for updates. The next step, "Making sure you're ready to install," appears, with a message to "Please wait." The setup then prompts for more space needed for the update, offering options to free up space on the C drive or connect an external storage device. The user selects the latter, and the progress bar shows the amount of free space available. The video concludes with the setup process still in progress, indicating the user's active engagement in updating their Windows 10 system.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker expresses frustration at having to sign another set of licenses and verifies that a product key works. He then notes that the system is checking for updates, which Windows tends to do often. Next, he describes how the system is making sure that it is ready to install, but no progress is shown. He mentions that waiting is needed, with processor speed impacting the wait time. Following that, the system is making sure the computer has enough space, but it turns out more space is needed for the update. The speaker highlights that the system provides options to free up more space, and that more space is needed to download and install the update. He inserts a flash drive with enough space, confirms the drive, and continues the update. The speaker wants a smooth and easy process, as the computer will not be used after this.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a computer desktop screen displaying a Windows 10 setup window, ready to install the operating system. The desktop background features a scenic image of a winding road at dusk, with a mountainous landscape and a sunset sky. The taskbar shows the time as 21:43. The setup window prompts the user to choose between installing Windows 10 Home and keeping personal files and apps, with the latter option checked. The user clicks the 'Install' button, transitioning to a blue screen with the message 'Installing Windows 10' and a progress bar indicating the installation process. The scene then shifts to a close-up of a blue HP laptop on a wooden table, displaying the same 'Installing Windows 10' screen. The background includes a wooden wall and a shelf with white candles. The installation process continues, with the progress bar advancing and the message 'Keep your PC on until this is done' appearing. The video concludes with the laptop screen showing 'Working on updates' and a progress percentage of 28%, advising not to turn off the computer. The environment remains consistent throughout, with the laptop on the wooden table and the background unchanged.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker explaining that he will stop the video and switch over to his phone. He states, "let's begin". The speaker then describes what occurred after he pressed "install," indicating that he can no longer use the phone, and that Windows 10 is installing for real. He mentions that the phone will restart several times during the process and that this is normal. He says, "this might take a while", and will check back in when it is almost finished. After the first restart, the phone will start installing some updates and, as the warning says, to not turn the pc off.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a dark screen featuring a bright blue Windows logo in the center, indicating the computer is in the process of booting up. A loading icon appears below the logo, suggesting the system is initializing. The screen remains dark with the Windows logo and loading icon visible, indicating the computer is still in the booting process. The scene then transitions to a whiteboard filled with various mathematical equations, diagrams, and notes written in blue and black marker. The text "Thanks for Watching" is prominently displayed in the center, with a red "Subscribe" button below it, encouraging viewers to subscribe to the channel. The whiteboard is cluttered with different mathematical concepts, including algebraic equations, calculus, and physics formulas, suggesting an educational or informative context. The video concludes with this whiteboard scene, emphasizing the educational content and a call to action for viewers to subscribe.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker, speaking in an instructional tone about a Windows 10 loading screen. He says, "once everything's good to go... you're going to see this loading screen... minimal sign-in things... working with Windows 10." He emphasizes how easy it is, ensuring that all files remain intact and that nothing has been moved. He concludes by saying "Thanks so much for watching. This is Falconator signing out." Subsequently, a soft "thump" sound effect is heard, immediately followed by a brief, pleasant-sounding jingle.
